verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 1:1
verses.text: Socrates, Book VII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 1:2
verses.text: Chapter I.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 1:3
verses.text: —Anthemius the Praetorian Prefect administers the Government of the East in Behalf of Young Theodosius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 1:4
verses.text: After the death of Arcadius on the first of May, during the consulate of Bassus and Philip,  his brother Honorius still governed the Western parts of the empire; but the administration of the East devolved on his son Theodosius the Younger, then only eight years old.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 1:5
verses.text: The management of public affairs was therefore intrusted to Anthemius the Praetorian prefect, grandson of that Philip who in the reign of Constantius ejected Paul from the see of Constantinople, and established Macedonius in his place.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 1:6
verses.text: By his directions Constantinople was surrounded with high walls.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 1:7
verses.text: He was esteemed and actually was the most prudent man of his time, and seldom did anything unadvisedly, but consulted with the most judicious of his friends respecting all practical matters, and especially with Troïlus  the sophist, who while excelling in philosophical attainments, was equal to Anthemius himself in political wisdom.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 1:8
verses.text: Wherefore almost all things were done with the concurrence of Troïlus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 2:2
verses.text: —Character and Conduct of Atticus Bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 2:3
verses.text: When Theodosius the emperor was in the eighth year of his age, Atticus was in the third year of his presidency over the church at Constantinople, a man as we have by anticipation said  distinguished alike for his learning, piety, and discretion, wherefore it came about that the churches under his episcopate attained a very flourishing condition.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 2:4
verses.text: For he not only united those of 'the household of faith,'  but also by his prudence called forth the admiration of the heretics, whom indeed he by no means desired to harass; but if he sometimes was obliged to impress them with the fear of himself, he soon afterward showed himself mild and clement toward them.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 2:5
verses.text: But indeed he did not neglect his studies; for he assiduously labored in perusing the writings of the ancients, and often spent whole nights in the task; and thus he could not be confused by the reasonings of the philosophers, and the fallacious subtleties of the sophists.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 2:6
verses.text: Besides this he was affable and entertaining in conversation, and ever ready to sympathize with the afflicted: and in a word, to sum up his excellences in the apostle's saying, 'He was made all things to all men.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 2:7
verses.text: '  Formerly while a presbyter, he had been accustomed, after composing his sermons, to commit them to memory, and then recite them in the church: but by diligent application he acquired confidence and made his instruction extemporaneous and eloquent.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 2:8
verses.text: His discourses however were not such as to be received with much applause by his auditors, nor to deserve to be committed to writing.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 2:9
verses.text: Let these particulars respecting his talents, erudition, and manners suffice.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 2:10
verses.text: We must now proceed to relate such things as are worthy of record, that happened in his time.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 3:2
verses.text: —Of Theodosius and Agapetus Bishops of Synada.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 3:3
verses.text: A certain Theodosius was bishop of Synada in Phrygia Pacata; he violently persecuted the heretics in that province—and there was a great number of them—and especially those of the Macedonian sect; he drove them out not only from the city, but also out of the country.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 3:4
verses.text: This course he pursued not from any precedent in the orthodox church, nor from the desire of propagating the true faith; but being enslaved by the love of filthy lucre, he was impelled by the avaricious motive of amassing money, by extorting it from the heretics.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 3:5
verses.text: To this end he made all sorts of attempts upon the Macedonians, putting arms into the hands of his clergy; and employing innumerable stratagems against them; nor did he refrain from delivering them up to the secular tribunals.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 3:6
verses.text: But he especially annoyed their bishop whose name was Agapetus: and finding the governors of the province were not invested with sufficient authority to punish heretics according to his wish, he went to Constantinople and petitioned for edicts of a more stringent nature from the Praetorian prefect.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 3:7
verses.text: While Theodosius was absent on this business, Agapetus who, as I have said, presided over the Macedonian sect, came to a wise and prudent conclusion.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 3:8
verses.text: Communicating with his clergy, he called all the people under his guidance together, and persuaded them to embrace the 'homoousian' faith.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 3:9
verses.text: On their acquiescing in this proposition, he proceeded immediately to the church attended not merely by his own adherents, but by the whole body of the people.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 3:10
verses.text: There having offered prayer, he took possession of the episcopal chair in which Theodosius was accustomed to seat himself; and preaching thenceforth the doctrine of consubstantiality, he reunited the people, and made himself master of the churches in the diocese of Synada.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 3:11
verses.text: Soon after these transactions, Theodosius returned to Synada, bringing with him extended powers from the prefect, and knowing nothing of what had taken place, he proceeded to the church just as he was.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 3:12
verses.text: Being forthwith unanimously expelled, he again betook himself to Constantinople; upon his arrival at that place he complained to Atticus, the bishop, of the treatment he had met with, and the manner in which he had been deprived of his bishopric.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 3:13
verses.text: Atticus perceiving that this movement had resulted advantageously to the church, consoled Theodosius as well as he could; recommending him to embrace with a contented mind a retired life, and thus sacrifice his own private interests to the public good.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 3:14
verses.text: He then wrote to Agapetus authorizing him to retain the episcopate, and bidding him be under no apprehension of being molested in consequence of Theodosius' grievance.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 4:2
verses.text: —A Paralytic Jew healed by Atticus in Baptism.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 4:3
verses.text: This was one important improvement in the circumstances of the Church, which happened during the administration of Atticus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 4:4
verses.text: Nor were these times without the attestation of miracles and healings.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 4:5
verses.text: For a certain Jew being a paralytic had been confined to his bed for many years; and as every sort of medical skill, and the prayers of his Jewish brethren had been resorted to but had availed nothing, he had recourse at length to Christian baptism, trusting in it as the only true remedy to be used.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 4:6
verses.text: When Atticus the bishop was informed of his wishes, he instructed him in the first principles of Christian truth, and having preached to him to hope in Christ, directed that he should be brought in his bed to the font.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 4:7
verses.text: The paralytic Jew receiving baptism with a sincere faith, as soon as he was taken out of the baptismal font found himself perfectly cured of his disease, and continued to enjoy sound health afterwards.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 4:8
verses.text: This miraculous power Christ vouchsafed to be manifested even in our times; and the fame of it caused many heathens to believe and be baptized.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 4:9
verses.text: But the Jews although zealously 'seeking after signs,'  not even the signs which actually took place induced to embrace the faith.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 4:10
verses.text: Such blessings were thus conferred by Christ upon men.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 5:2
verses.text: —The Presbyter Sabbatius, formerly a Jew, separates from the Novatians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 5:3
verses.text: Many, however, making no account of these events yielded to their own depravity; for not only did the Jews continue in unbelief after this miracle, but others also who love to follow them were shown to hold views similar to theirs.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 5:4
verses.text: Among these was Sabbatius, of whom mention has before been made;  who not being content with the dignity of presbyter to which he had attained, but aiming at a bishopric from the beginning, separated himself from the church of the Novatians, making a pretext of observing the Jewish Passover.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 5:5
verses.text: Holding therefore schismatic assemblies apart from his own bishop Sisinnius, in a place named Xerolophus, where the forum of Arcadius now is, he ventured on the performance of an act deserving the severest punishments.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 5:6
verses.text: Reading one day at one of these meetings that passage in the Gospel where it is said,  'Now it was the Feast of the Jews called the Passover,' he added what was never written nor heard of before: 'Cursed be he that celebrates the Passover out of the days of unleavened bread.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 5:7
verses.text: ' When these words were reported among the people, the more simple of the Novatian laity, deceived by this artifice, flocked to him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 5:8
verses.text: But his fraudulent fabrication was of no avail to him; for his forgery issued in most disastrous consequences.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 5:9
verses.text: For shortly afterwards he kept this feast in anticipation of the Christian Easter; and many according to their custom flocked to him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 5:10
verses.text: While they were passing the night in the accustomed vigils, a panic as if caused by evil spirits fell upon them, as if Sisinnius their bishop were coming with a multitude of persons to attack them.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 5:11
verses.text: From the perturbation that might be expected in such a case, and their being shut up at night in a confined place, they trod upon one another, insomuch that above seventy of them were crushed to death.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 5:12
verses.text: On this account many deserted Sabbatius: some however, holding his ignorant prejudice, remained with him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 5:13
verses.text: In what way Sabbatius, by a violation of his oath, afterwards managed to get himself ordained a bishop, we shall relate hereafter.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 6:2
verses.text: —The Leaders of Arianism at this Time.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 6:3
verses.text: Dorotheus bishop of the Arians, who, as we have said,  was translated by that sect from Antioch to Constantinople, having attained the age of one hundred and nineteen years, died on the 6th of November, in the seventh consulate of Honorius, and the second of Theodosius Augustus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 6:4
verses.text: After him Barbas presided over the Arian sect, in whose time the Arian faction was favored by possessing two very eloquent members, both having the rank of presbyter, one of whom was named Timothy, and the other George.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 6:5
verses.text: Now George excelled in Grecian literature; Timothy, on the other hand, was proficient in the sacred Scriptures.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 6:6
verses.text: George indeed constantly had the writings of Aristotle and Plato in his hands: Timothy found his inspiration in Origen; he also evinced in his public expositions of the holy Scriptures no inconsiderable acquaintance with the Hebrew language.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 6:7
verses.text: Now Timothy had formerly identified himself with the sect of the Psathyrians;  but George had been ordained by Barbas.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 6:8
verses.text: I have myself conversed with Timothy, and was exceedingly struck by the readiness with which he would answer the most difficult questions, and clear up the most obscure passages in the Divine oracles; he also invariably quoted Origen as an unquestionable authority in confirmation of his own utterances.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 6:9
verses.text: But it is astonishing to me that these two men should continue to uphold the heresy of the Arians; the one being so conversant with Plato, and the other having Origen so frequently on his lips.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 6:10
verses.text: For Plato does not say that the second and third cause, as he usually terms them, had a beginning of existence:  and Origen everywhere acknowledges the Son to be co-eternal  with the Father.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 6:11
verses.text: Nevertheless although they remained connected with their own church, still they unconsciously changed the Arian sect for the better, and displaced many of the blasphemies of Arius by their own teachings.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 6:12
verses.text: But enough of these persons.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 6:13
verses.text: Sisinnius bishop of the Novatians dying under the same consulate, Chrysanthus was ordained in his place, of whom we shall have to speak by and by.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 7:2
verses.text: —Cyril succeeds Theophilus Bishop of Alexandria.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 7:3
verses.text: Shortly afterwards Theophilus bishop of Alexandria having fallen into a lethargic state, died on the 15th of October,  in the ninth consulate of Honorius, and the fifth of Theodosius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 7:4
verses.text: A great contest immediately arose about the appointment of a successor, some seeking to place Timothy the archdeacon in the episcopal chair; and others desiring Cyril, who was a nephew of Theophilus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 7:5
verses.text: A tumult having arisen on this account among the people, Abundantius, the commander of the troops in Egypt, took sides with Timothy.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 7:6
verses.text: [Yet the partisans of Cyril triumphed.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 7:7
verses.text: ]  Whereupon on the third day after the death of Theophilus, Cyril came into possession of the episcopate, with greater power than Theophilus had ever exercised.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 7:8
verses.text: For from that time the bishopric of Alexandria went beyond the limits of its sacerdotal functions, and assumed the administration of secular matters.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 7:9
verses.text: Cyril immediately therefore shut up the churches of the Novatians at Alexandria, and took possession of all their consecrated vessels and ornaments; and then stripped their bishop Theopemptus of all that he had.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:2
verses.text: —Propagation of Christianity among the Persians by Maruthas Bishop of Mesopotamia.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:3
verses.text: About this same time it happened that Christianity was disseminated in Persia, by reason of the following causes.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:4
verses.text: Frequent embassies were sent to and fro between the sovereigns of Persia and the Roman empire, for which there were continual occasions.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:5
verses.text: Necessity brought it about at that time that the Roman emperor thought proper to send Maruthas bishop of Mesopotamia, who has been before mentioned,  on a mission to the king of the Persians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:6
verses.text: The king discovering great piety in the man treated him with great honor, and gave heed to him as one who was indeed beloved of God.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:7
verses.text: This excited the jealousy of the magi,  whose influence is considerable over the Persian monarch, for they feared lest he should persuade the king to embrace Christianity.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:8
verses.text: For Maruthas had by his prayers cured the king of a violent headache to which he had been long subject, and which the magi had been unable to relieve.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:9
verses.text: The magicians therefore had recourse to this deception.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:10
verses.text: As the Persians worship fire, and the king was accustomed to pay his adorations in a certain edifice to the fire which was kept perpetually burning, they concealed a man underneath the sacred hearth, ordering him to make this exclamation at the time of day when the king was accustomed to perform his devotion! 'The king should be thrust out because he is guilty of impiety, in imagining a Christian priest to be loved by the Deity.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:11
verses.text: ' When Isdigerdes—for that was the king's name—heard these words, he determined to dismiss Maruthas, notwithstanding the reverence with which he regarded him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:12
verses.text: But Maruthas being truly a God-loving man, by the earnestness of his prayers, detected the imposition of the magi.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:13
verses.text: Going to the king therefore he addressed him thus: 'Be not deluded, O king,' said he, 'but when you again enter that edifice and hear the same voice, explore the ground below, and you will discover the fraud.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:14
verses.text: For it is not the fire that speaks, but human contrivance does this.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:15
verses.text: ' The king received the suggestion of Maruthas and went as usual to the little house where the ever-burning fire was.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:16
verses.text: When he again heard the same voice, he ordered the hearth to be dug up; whereupon the impostor, who uttered the supposed words of the Deity, was discovered.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:17
verses.text: Becoming indignant at the deception thus attempted the king commanded that the tribe of the magi should be decimated.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:18
verses.text: When this was effected he permitted Maruthas to erect churches wherever he wished; and from that time the Christian religion was diffused among the Persians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:19
verses.text: Then Maruthas being recalled went to Constantinople; not long afterwards however, he was again sent as ambassador to the Persian court.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:20
verses.text: Again the magi devised contrivances so as by all possible means to prevent the king from giving him audience.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:21
verses.text: One of their devices was to cause a most disgusting smell where the king was accustomed to go, and then accuse the Christians of being the authors of it.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:22
verses.text: The king however having already had occasion to suspect the magi, very diligently and closely scrutinized the matter; and again the authors of the nuisance were detected.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:23
verses.text: Wherefore he punished several of them, and held Maruthas in still higher honor.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:24
verses.text: For the Romans as a nation he had much regard, and prized good feeling on their part very highly.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:25
verses.text: Nay, he almost embraced the Christian faith himself, as Maruthas in conjunction with Abdas bishop of Persia gave another experimental proof of its power: for these two by giving themselves to much fasting and prayer, had cast out a demon with which the king's son was possessed.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:26
verses.text: But the death of Isdigerdes  prevented his making an open profession of Christianity.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 8:27
verses.text: The kingdom then devolved on Vararanes his son, in whose time the treaty between the Romans and Persians was broken as we shall have occasion to narrate a little later.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 9:2
verses.text: —The Bishops of Antioch and Rome.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 9:3
verses.text: During this period upon the death of Flavian  Porphyry received the episcopate of Antioch, and after him Alexander  was set over that church.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 9:4
verses.text: But at Rome, Damasus having held that bishopric eighteen years Siricius succeeded him;  and Siricius having presided there fifteen years, Anastasius held sway over the church for three years; after Anastasius Innocent [was promoted to the same see].

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 9:5
verses.text: He was the first persecutor of the Novatians at Rome, and many of their churches he took away.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 10:2
verses.text: —Rome taken and sacked by Alaric.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 10:3
verses.text: About this same time  it happened that Rome was taken by the barbarians; for a certain Alaric, a barbarian who had been an ally of the Romans, and had served as an ally with the emperor Theodosius in the war against the usurper Eugenius, having on that account been honored with Roman dignities, was unable to bear his good fortune.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 10:4
verses.text: He did not choose to assume imperial authority, but retiring from Constantinople went into the Western parts, and arriving at Illyricum immediately laid waste the whole country.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 10:5
verses.text: As he marched, however, the Thessalians opposed him at the mouths of the river Peneus, whence there is a pass over Mount Pindus to Nicopolis in Epirus; and coming to an engagement, the Thessalians killed about three thousand of his men.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 10:6
verses.text: After this the barbarians that were with him destroying everything in their way, at last took Rome itself, which they pillaged, burning the greatest number of the magnificent structures and other admirable works of art it contained.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 10:7
verses.text: The money and valuable articles they plundered and divided among themselves.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 10:8
verses.text: Many of the principal senators they put to death on a variety of pretexts.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 10:9
verses.text: Moreover, Alaric in mockery of the imperial dignity, proclaimed one Attalus  emperor, whom he ordered to be attended with all the insignia of sovereignty on one day, and to be exhibited in the habit of a slave on the next.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 10:10
verses.text: After these achievements he made a precipitate retreat, a report having reached him that the emperor Theodosius had sent an army to fight him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 10:11
verses.text: Nor was this report a fictitious one; for the imperial forces were actually on their way; but Alaric, not waiting for the materialization of the rumor, decamped and escaped.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 10:12
verses.text: It is said that as he was advancing towards Rome, a pious monk exhorted him not to delight in the perpetuation of such atrocities, and no longer to rejoice in slaughter and blood.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 10:13
verses.text: To whom Alaric replied, 'I am not going on in this course of my own will; but there is a something that irresistibly impels me daily, saying, 'Proceed to Rome, and desolate that city.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 10:14
verses.text: ' Such was the career of this person.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 11:2
verses.text: —The Bishops of Rome.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 11:3
verses.text: After Innocent, Zosimus governed the Roman church for two years: and after him Boniface  presided over it for three years.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 11:4
verses.text: He was succeeded by Celestinus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 11:5
verses.text: And this Celestinus took away the churches from the Novatians at Rome also, and obliged Rusticula their bishop to hold his meetings secretly in private houses.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 11:6
verses.text: Until this time the Novatians had flourished exceedingly in Rome, possessing many churches there, which were attended by large congregations.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 11:7
verses.text: But envy attacked them also, as soon as the Roman episcopate, like that of Alexandria, extended itself beyond the limits of ecclesiastical jurisdiction, and degenerated into its present state of secular domination.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 11:8
verses.text: For thenceforth the bishops would not suffer even those who agreed with them in matters of faith to enjoy the privilege of assembling in peace, but stripped them of all they possessed, praising them merely for these agreements in faith.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 11:9
verses.text: The bishops of Constantinople kept themselves free from this [sort of conduct]; inasmuch as in addition to tolerating them and permitting them to hold their assemblies within the city, as I have already stated,  they treated them with every mark of Christian regard.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 12:2
verses.text: —Of Chrysanthus Bishop of the Novatians at Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 12:3
verses.text: After the death of Sisinnius, Chrysanthus was constrained to take upon him the episcopal office.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 12:4
verses.text: He was the son of Marcian the predecessor of Sisinnius, and having had a military appointment in the palace at an early age, he was subsequently under Theodosius the Great made governor  of Italy, and after that lord-lieutenant  of the British Isles, in both which capacities he elicited for himself the highest admiration.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 12:5
verses.text: Returning to Constantinople at an advanced age, earnestly desiring to be constituted prefect of that city, he was made bishop of the Novatians against his will.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 12:6
verses.text: For as Sisinnius, when at the point of death, had referred to him as a most suitable person to occupy the see, the people regarding this declaration as law, sought to have him ordained forthwith.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 12:7
verses.text: Now as Chrysanthus attempted to avoid having this dignity forced upon him, Sabbatius imagining that a seasonable opportunity was now afforded him of making himself master of the churches, and making no account of the oath by which he had bound himself,  procured his own ordination at the hands of a few insignificant bishops.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 12:8
verses.text: Among these was Hermogenes, who had been excommunicated with curses by [Sabbatius] himself on account of his blasphemous writings.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 12:9
verses.text: But this perjured procedure of Sabbatius was of no avail to him: for the people disgusted with his obstreperousness, used every effort to discover the retreat of Chrysanthus; and having found him secluded in Bithynia, they brought him back by force, and invested him with the bishopric.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 12:10
verses.text: He was a man of unsurpassed modesty and prudence; and thus he established and enlarged the churches of the Novatians at Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 12:11
verses.text: Moreover he was the first to distribute gold among the poor out of his own private property.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 12:12
verses.text: Furthermore he would receive nothing from the churches but two loaves of the consecrated bread  every Lord's day.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 12:13
verses.text: So anxious was he to promote the advantage of his own church, that he drew Ablabius, the most eminent orator of that time from the school of Troïlus, and ordained him a presbyter; whose sermons are in circulation being remarkably elegant and full of point.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 12:14
verses.text: But Ablabius was afterwards promoted to the bishopric of the church of the Novatians at Nicaea, where he also taught rhetoric at the same time.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:2
verses.text: —Conflict between the Christians and Jews at Alexandria: and breach between the Bishop Cyril and the Prefect Orestes.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:3
verses.text: About this same time it happened that the Jewish inhabitants were driven out of Alexandria by Cyril the bishop on the following account.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:4
verses.text: The Alexandrian public is more delighted with tumult than any other people: and if at any time it should find a pretext, breaks forth into the most intolerable excesses; for it never ceases from its turbulence without bloodshed.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:5
verses.text: It happened on the present occasion that a disturbance arose among the populace, not from a cause of any serious importance, but out of an evil that has become very popular in almost all cities, viz.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:6
verses.text: a fondness for dancing exhibitions.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:7
verses.text: In consequence of the Jews being disengaged from business on the Sabbath, and spending their time, not in hearing the Law, but in theatrical amusements, dancers usually collect great crowds on that day, and disorder is almost invariably produced.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:8
verses.text: And although this was in some degree controlled by the governor of Alexandria, nevertheless the Jews continued opposing these measures.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:9
verses.text: And although they are always hostile toward the Christians they were roused to still greater opposition against them on account of the dancers.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:10
verses.text: When therefore Orestes the prefect was publishing an edict—for so they are accustomed to call public notices—in the theatre for the regulation of the shows, some of the bishop Cyril's party were present to learn the nature of the orders about to be issued.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:11
verses.text: There was among them a certain Hierax, a teacher of the rudimental branches of literature, and one who was a very enthusiastic listener of the bishop Cyril's sermons, and made himself conspicuous by his forwardness in applauding.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:12
verses.text: When the Jews observed this person in the theatre, they immediately cried out that he had come there for no other purpose than to excite sedition among the people.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:13
verses.text: Now Orestes had long regarded with jealousy the growing power of the bishops, because they encroached on the jurisdiction of the authorities appointed by the emperor, especially as Cyril wished to set spies over his proceedings; he therefore ordered Hierax to be seized, and publicly subjected him to the torture in the theatre.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:14
verses.text: Cyril, on being informed of this, sent for the principal Jews, and threatened them with the utmost severities unless they desisted from their molestation of the Christians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:15
verses.text: The Jewish populace on hearing these menaces, instead of suppressing their violence, only became more furious, and were led to form conspiracies for the destruction of the Christians; one of these was of so desperate a character as to cause their entire expulsion from Alexandria; this I shall now describe.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:16
verses.text: Having agreed that each one of them should wear a ring on his finger made of the bark of a palm branch, for the sake of mutual recognition, they determined to make a nightly attack on the Christians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:17
verses.text: They therefore sent persons into the streets to raise an outcry that the church named after Alexander was on fire.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:18
verses.text: Thus many Christians on hearing this ran out, some from one direction and some from another, in great anxiety to save their church.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:19
verses.text: The Jews immediately fell upon and slew them; readily distinguishing each other by their rings.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:20
verses.text: At daybreak the authors of this atrocity could not be concealed: and Cyril, accompanied by an immense crowd of people, going to their synagogues—for so they call their house of prayer—took them away from them, and drove the Jews out of the city, permitting the multitude to plunder their goods.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:21
verses.text: Thus the Jews who had inhabited the city from the time of Alexander the Macedonian were expelled from it, stripped of all they possessed, and dispersed some in one direction and some in another.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:22
verses.text: One of them, a physician  named Adamantius, fled to Atticus bishop of Constantinople, and professing Christianity, some time afterwards returned to Alexandria and fixed his residence there.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:23
verses.text: But Orestes the governor of Alexandria was filled with great indignation at these transactions, and was excessively grieved that a city of such magnitude should have been suddenly bereft of so large a portion of its population; he therefore at once communicated the whole affair to the emperor.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:24
verses.text: Cyril also wrote to him, describing the outrageous conduct of the Jews; and in the meanwhile sent persons to Orestes who should mediate concerning a reconciliation: for this the people had urged him to do.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:25
verses.text: And when Orestes refused to listen to friendly advances, Cyril extended toward him the book of gospels,  believing that respect for religion would induce him to lay aside his resentment.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 13:26
verses.text: When, however, even this had no pacific effect on the prefect, but he persisted in implacable hostility against the bishop, the following event afterwards occurred.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 14:2
verses.text: —The Monks of Nitria come down and raise a Sedition against the Prefect of Alexandria.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 14:3
verses.text: Some of the monks inhabiting the mountains of Nitria, of a very fiery disposition, whom Theophilus some time before had unjustly armed against Dioscorus and his brethren, being again transported with an ardent zeal, resolved to fight in behalf of Cyril.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 14:4
verses.text: About five hundred of them therefore quitting their monasteries, came into the city; and meeting the prefect in his chariot, they called him a pagan idolater, and applied to him many other abusive epithets.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 14:5
verses.text: He supposing this to be a snare laid for him by Cyril, exclaimed that he was a Christian, and had been baptized by Atticus the bishop at Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 14:6
verses.text: As they gave but little heed to his protestations, and a certain one of them named Ammonius threw a stone at Orestes which struck him on the head and covered him with the blood that flowed from the wound, all the guards with a few exceptions fled, plunging into the crowd, some in one direction and some in another, fearing to be stoned to death.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 14:7
verses.text: Meanwhile the populace of Alexandria ran to the rescue of the governor, and put the rest of the monks to flight; but having secured Ammonius they delivered him up to the prefect.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 14:8
verses.text: He immediately put him publicly to the torture, which was inflicted with such severity that he died under the effects of it: and not long after he gave an account to the emperors of what had taken place.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 14:9
verses.text: Cyril also on the other hand forwarded his statement of the matter to the emperor: and causing the body of Ammonius to be deposited in a certain church, he gave him the new appellation of Thaumasius,  ordering him to be enrolled among the martyrs, and eulogizing his magnanimity in church as that of one who had fallen in a conflict in defence of piety.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 14:10
verses.text: But the more sober-minded, although Christians, did not accept Cyril's prejudiced estimate of him; for they well knew that he had suffered the punishment due to his rashness, and that he had not lost his life under the torture because he would not deny Christ.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 14:11
verses.text: And Cyril himself being conscious of this, suffered the recollection of the circumstance to be gradually obliterated by silence.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 14:12
verses.text: But the animosity between Cyril and Orestes did not by any means subside at this point, but was kindled  afresh by an occurrence similar to the preceding.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 15:2
verses.text: —Of Hypatia the Female Philosopher.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 15:3
verses.text: There was a woman at Alexandria named Hypatia,  daughter of the philosopher Theon, who made such attainments in literature and science, as to far surpass all the philosophers of her own time.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 15:4
verses.text: Having succeeded to the school of Plato and Plotinus, she explained the principles of philosophy to her auditors, many of whom came from a distance to receive her instructions.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 15:5
verses.text: On account of the self-possession and ease of manner, which she had acquired in consequence of the cultivation of her mind, she not unfrequently appeared in public in presence of the magistrates.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 15:6
verses.text: Neither did she feel abashed in coming to an assembly of men.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 15:7
verses.text: For all men on account of her extraordinary dignity and virtue admired her the more.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 15:8
verses.text: Yet even she fell a victim to the political jealousy which at that time prevailed.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 15:9
verses.text: For as she had frequent interviews with Orestes, it was calumniously reported among the Christian populace, that it was she who prevented Orestes from being reconciled to the bishop.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 15:10
verses.text: Some of them therefore, hurried away by a fierce and bigoted zeal, whose ringleader was a reader named Peter, waylaid her returning home, and dragging her from her carriage, they took her to the church called Caesareum, where they completely stripped her, and then murdered her with tiles.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 15:11
verses.text: After tearing her body in pieces, they took her mangled limbs to a place called Cinaron, and there burnt them.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 15:12
verses.text: This affair brought not the least opprobrium, not only upon Cyril,  but also upon the whole Alexandrian church.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 15:13
verses.text: And surely nothing can be farther from the spirit of Christianity than the allowance of massacres, fights, and transactions of that sort.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 15:14
verses.text: This happened in the month of March during Lent, in the fourth year of Cyril's episcopate, under the tenth consulate of Honorius, and the sixth of Theodosius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 16:2
verses.text: —The Jews commit Another Outrage upon the Christians and are punished.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 16:3
verses.text: Soon afterwards the Jews renewed their malevolent and impious practices against the Christians, and drew down upon themselves deserved punishment.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 16:4
verses.text: At a place named Inmestar, situated between Chalcis and Antioch in Syria, the Jews were amusing themselves in their usual way with a variety of sports.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 16:5
verses.text: In this way they indulged in many absurdities, and at length impelled by drunkenness they were guilty of scoffing at Christians and even Christ himself; and in derision of the cross and those who put their trust in the Crucified One, they seized a Christian boy, and having bound him to a cross, began to laugh and sneer at him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 16:6
verses.text: But in a little while becoming so transported with fury, they scourged the child until he died under their hands.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 16:7
verses.text: This conduct occasioned a sharp conflict between them and the Christians; and as soon as the emperors were informed of the circumstance, they issued orders to the governor of the province to find out and punish the delinquents.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 16:8
verses.text: And thus the Jewish inhabitants of this place paid the penalty for the wickedness they had committed in their impious sport.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:2
verses.text: —Miracle performed by Paul Bishop of the Novatians at the Baptism of a Jewish Impostor.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:3
verses.text: About this time Chrysanthus bishop of the Novatians, after presiding over the churches of his own sect seven years, died on the 26th of August, under the consulate of Monaxius and Plintha.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:4
verses.text: He was succeeded in the bishopric by Paul, who had formerly been a teacher of the Latin language: but afterwards, setting aside the Latin language, had devoted himself to an ascetic course of life; and having founded a monastery of religious men, he adopted a mode of living not very different from that pursued by the monks in the desert.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:5
verses.text: In fact I myself found him just such a person as Evagrius  says the monks dwelling in the deserts ought to be; imitating them in continued fastings, silence, abstinence from animal food, and for the most part abstaining also from the use of oil and wine.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:6
verses.text: He was, moreover, solicitous about the wants of the poor to as great an extent as any other man; he untiringly visited those who were in prison, and in behalf of many criminals interceded with the judges, who readily attended to him on account of his eminent piety.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:7
verses.text: But why should I lengthen my account of him? For I am about to mention a deed done by him which is well worthy of being recorded in writing.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:8
verses.text: A certain Jewish impostor, pretending to be a convert to Christianity, was in the habit of being baptized often  and by that artifice he amassed a good deal of money.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:9
verses.text: After having deceived many of the Christian sects by this fraud—for he received baptism from the Arians and Macedonians—as there remained no others to practise his hypocrisy upon, he at length came to Paul bishop of the Novatians, and declaring that he earnestly desired baptism, requested that he might obtain it at his hand.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:10
verses.text: Paul commended the determination of the Jew, but told him he could not perform that rite for him, until he had been instructed in the fundamental principles of the faith, and given himself to fasting and prayer for many days.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:11
verses.text: The Jew compelled to fast against his will became the more importunate in his request for baptism; now as Paul did not wish to discourage him by longer delays, since he was so urgent, consented to grant his request, and made all the necessary preparations for the baptism.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:12
verses.text: Having purchased a white vestment for him, he ordered the font to be filled with water, and then led the Jew to it in order to baptize him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:13
verses.text: But a certain invisible power of God caused the water suddenly to disappear.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:14
verses.text: The bishop, of course, and those present, had not the least suspicion of the real cause, but imagined that the water had escaped by the channels underneath, by means of which they are accustomed to empty the font; these passages were therefore very carefully closed, and the font filled again.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:15
verses.text: Again, however, as the Jew was taken there a second time, the water vanished as before.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:16
verses.text: Then Paul addressing the Jew, said, 'Either you are an evil-doer, wretched man, or an ignorant person who has already been baptized.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:17
verses.text: ' The people having crowded together to witness this miracle, one among them recognized the Jew, and identified him as having been baptized by Atticus, the bishop, a little while before.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 17:18
verses.text: Such was the portent wrought by the hands of Paul bishop of the Novatians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:2
verses.text: —Renewal of Hostilities between the Romans and Persians after the Death of Isdigerdes King of the Persians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:3
verses.text: Isdigerdes king of the Persians, who had in no way molested the Christians in his dominions, having died,  his son Vararanes by name succeeded him in the kingdom.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:4
verses.text: This prince yielding to the influence of the magi, persecuted the Christians there with rigor, by inflicting on them a variety of Persian punishments and tortures.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:5
verses.text: They were therefore on account of the oppression obliged to desert their country and seek refuge among the Romans, entreating them not to suffer them to be completely extirpated.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:6
verses.text: Atticus the bishop received these suppliants with great benignity, and did his utmost to help them in whatsoever way it was possible: accordingly he made the emperor Theodosius acquainted with the facts.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:7
verses.text: It happened at the same time that another grievance of the Romans against Persians came to light.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:8
verses.text: The Persians, that is to say, would not send back the laborers in the gold mines who had been hired from among the Romans; and they also plundered the Roman merchants.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:9
verses.text: The bad feeling which these things produced was greatly increased by the flight of the Persian Christians into the Roman territories.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:10
verses.text: For the Persian king immediately sent an embassy to demand the fugitives.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:11
verses.text: But the Romans were by no means disposed to deliver them up; not only as desirous of defending their suppliants, but also because they were ready to do anything for the sake of the Christian religion.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:12
verses.text: For which reason they chose rather to renew the war with the Persians, than to suffer the Christians to be miserably destroyed.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:13
verses.text: The league was accordingly broken, and a fierce war followed.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:14
verses.text: Of which war I deem it not unseasonable to give some brief account.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:15
verses.text: The Roman emperor first sent a body of troops under the command of the general Ardaburius;  who making an irruption through Armenia into Persia, ravaged one of its provinces called Azazene.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:16
verses.text: Narsaeus the Persian general marched against him with the Persian army; but on coming to an engagement he was defeated, and obliged to retreat.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:17
verses.text: Afterwards he judged it advantageous to make an unexpected irruption through Mesopotamia into the Roman territories there unguarded, thinking by this means to be revenged on the enemy.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:18
verses.text: But this design of Narsaeus did not escape the observation of the Roman general.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:19
verses.text: Having therefore plundered Azazene, he then himself also hastily marched into Mesopotamia.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:20
verses.text: Wherefore Narsaeus, although furnished with a large army, was prevented from invading the Roman provinces; but arriving at Nisibis—a city in the possession of the Persians situated on the frontiers of both empires—he sent Ardaburius desiring that they might make mutual arrangements about carrying on the war, and appoint a time and place for an engagement.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:21
verses.text: But he said to the messengers, 'Tell Narsaeus that the Roman emperors will not fight when it pleases him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:22
verses.text: ' The emperor perceiving that the Persian was mustering his whole force, made additional levies to his army, and put his whole trust in God for the victory: and that the king was not without immediate benefit from this pious confidence the following circumstance proves.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:23
verses.text: As the Constantinopolitans were in great consternation, and apprehensive respecting the issue of the war, angels from God appeared to some persons in Bithynia who were travelling to Constantinople on their own affairs, and bade them tell the people not to be alarmed, but pray to God and be assured that the Romans would be conquerors.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:24
verses.text: For they said that they themselves were appointed by God to defend them.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:25
verses.text: When this message was circulated it not only comforted the residents of the city, but rendered the soldiers more courageous.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:26
verses.text: The seat of war being transferred, as we have said, from Armenia to Mesopotamia, the Romans shut up the Persians in the city of Nisibis, which they besieged; and having constructed wooden towers which they advanced by means of machines to the walls, they slew great numbers of those who defended them, as well as of those who ran to their assistance.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:27
verses.text: When Vararanes the Persian monarch learned that his province of Azazene on the one hand had been desolated, and that on the other his army was closely besieged in the city of Nisibis, he resolved to march in person with all his forces against the Romans: but dreading the Roman valor, he implored the aid of the Saracens, who were then governed by a warlike chief named Alamundarus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:28
verses.text: This prince accordingly brought with him a large reinforcement of Saracen auxiliaries, exhorted the king of the Persians to fear nothing, for that he would soon reduce the Romans under his power, and deliver Antioch in Syria into his hands.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:29
verses.text: But the event did not realize these promises; for God infused into the minds of the Saracens a terrible panic; and imagining that the Roman army was falling upon them, and finding no other way of escape, they precipitated themselves, armed as they were, into the river Euphrates, wherein nearly one hundred thousand of them were drowned.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:30
verses.text: Such was the nature of the panic.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:31
verses.text: The Romans besieging Nisibis, understanding that the king of Persia was bringing with him a great number of elephants, became alarmed in their turn, burnt all the machines they had used in carrying on the siege, and retired into their own country.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 18:32
verses.text: What engagements afterwards took place, and how Areobindus another Roman general killed the bravest of the Persians in single combat, and by what means Ardaburius destroyed seven Persian commanders in an ambuscade, and in what manner Vitian another Roman general vanquished the remnant of the Saracen forces, I believe I ought to pass by, lest I should digress too far from my subject.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 19:2
verses.text: —Of Palladius the Courier.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 19:3
verses.text: How the Emperor Theodosius received intelligence of what was done in an incredibly short space of time, and how he was quickly informed of events taking place far away, I shall attempt to explain.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 19:4
verses.text: For he had the good fortune to possess among his subjects a man endowed with extraordinary energy both of body and mind, named Palladius; who rode so vigorously that he would reach the frontiers of the Roman and Persian dominions in three days,  and again return to Constantinople in as many more.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 19:5
verses.text: The same individual traversed other parts of the world on missions from the emperor with equal celerity: so that an eloquent man once said not unaptly, 'This man by his speed proves the vast expanse of the Roman Empire to be little.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 19:6
verses.text: ' The king of the Persians himself was astonished at the expeditious feats which were related to him of this courier: but we must be content with the above details concerning him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:1
verses.text: Chapter XX.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:2
verses.text: —A Second Overthrow of the Persians by the Romans.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:3
verses.text: Now the emperor of the Romans dwelling in Constantinople being fully aware that God had plainly given him the victory was so benevolent that although those under him had been successful in war nevertheless he desired to make peace; and to that end he dispatched Helion, a man in whom he placed the greatest confidence, with a commission to enter into a pacific treaty with the Persians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:4
verses.text: Helion having arrived in Mesopotamia, at the place where the Romans for their own security had formed a trench, sent before him as his deputy Maximin an eloquent man who was the associate of Ardaburius the commander-in-chief of the army, to make preliminary arrangements concerning the terms of peace.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:5
verses.text: Maximin on coming into the presence of the Persian king, said he had been sent to him on this matter, not by the Roman emperor, but by his generals; for he said this war was not even known to the emperor, and if known would be considered insignificant by him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:6
verses.text: And as the sovereign of Persia had gladly decided to receive the embassy,—for his troops were suffering from want of provisions,—there came to him that corps among them which is distinguished by the name of 'the Immortals.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:7
verses.text: '  This is a body of brave men numbering about ten thousand—and counselled the king not to listen to any overtures for peace, until they should have made an attack upon the Romans, who, they said, were now become extremely incautious.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:8
verses.text: The king approving their advice, ordered the ambassador to be imprisoned and a guard set over him, and permitted the Immortals to put their design upon the Romans into execution.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:9
verses.text: They therefore, on arriving at the place appointed, divided themselves into two bands, with a view to surround some portion of the Roman army.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:10
verses.text: The Romans observing but one body of Persians approaching them, prepared themselves to receive it, not having seen the other division, in consequence of their suddenly rushing forth to battle.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:11
verses.text: But just as the engagement was about to commence, Divine Providence so ordered it, that another division of the Roman army under Procopius a general emerged from behind a certain hill and perceiving their comrades in danger, attacked the Persians in the rear.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:12
verses.text: Thus were they, who but a little before had surrounded the Romans, themselves encompassed.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:13
verses.text: Having utterly destroyed these in a short time, the Romans turned upon those who broke forth from their ambuscade and in like manner slew every one of them with darts.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:14
verses.text: In this way those who by the Persians were termed 'the Immortals' were all of them shown to be mortal, Christ having executed this vengeance upon the Persians because they had shed the blood of so many of his pious worshippers.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:15
verses.text: The king of the Persians on being informed of the disaster, pretended to be ignorant of what had taken place, and ordered the embassy to be admitted, he thus addressing the ambassador: 'I agree to the peace, not as yielding to the Romans, but to gratify you, whom I have found to be the most prudent of all the Romans.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 20:16
verses.text: ' Thus was that war concluded which had been undertaken on account of the suffering Christians in Persia, under the consulate of the two Augusti,  being the thirteenth of Honorius, and the tenth of Theodosius, in the fourth year of the 300th Olympiad: and with it terminated the persecution which had been excited in Persia against the Christians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 21:1
verses.text: Chapter XXI.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 21:2
verses.text: —Kind Treatment of the Persian Captives by Acacius Bishop of Amida.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 21:3
verses.text: A noble action of Acacius bishop of Amida, at that time greatly enhanced his reputation among all men.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 21:4
verses.text: As the Roman soldiery would on no consideration restore to the Persian king the captives whom they had taken, these captives, about seven thousand in number, were being destroyed by famine in devastating Azazene, and this greatly distressed the king of the Persians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 21:5
verses.text: Then Acacius thought such a matter was by no means to be trifled with; having therefore assembled his clergy, he thus addressed them: 'Our God, my brethren, needs neither dishes nor cups; for he neither eats nor drinks, nor is in want of anything.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 21:6
verses.text: Since then, by the liberality of its faithful members the church possesses many vessels both of gold and silver, it behooves us to sell them, that by the money thus raised we may be able to redeem the prisoners and also supply them with food.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 21:7
verses.text: ' Having said these things and many others similar to these, he ordered the vessels to be melted down, and from the proceeds paid the soldiers a ransom for their captives, whom he supported for some time; and then furnishing them with what was needful for their journey, sent them back to their sovereign.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 21:8
verses.text: This benevolence on the part of the excellent Acacius, astonished the king of the Persians, as if the Romans were accustomed to conquer their enemies as well by their beneficence in peace as their prowess in war.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 21:9
verses.text: They say also that the Persian king wished that Acacius should come into his presence, that he might have the pleasure of beholding such a man; a wish which by the emperor Theodosius' order was soon gratified.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 21:10
verses.text: So signal a victory having through Divine favor been achieved by the Romans, many who were illustrious for their eloquence, wrote panegyrics in honor of the emperor, and recited them in public.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 21:11
verses.text: The empress herself also composed a poem in heroic verse: for she had excellent literary taste; being the daughter of Leontius the Athenian sophist, she had been instructed in every kind of learning by her father; Atticus the bishop had baptized her a little while previous to her marriage with the emperor, and had then given her the Christian name of Eudocia,  instead of her pagan one of Athenaïs.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 21:12
verses.text: Many, as I have said, produced eulogiums on this occasion.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 21:13
verses.text: Some, indeed, were stimulated by the desire of being noticed by the emperor; while others were anxious to display their talents to the masses, being unwilling that the attainments they had made by dint of great exertion should lie buried in obscurity.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:1
verses.text: Chapter XXII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:2
verses.text: —Virtues of the Emperor Theodosius the Younger.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:3
verses.text: But although I am neither eager for the notice of the emperor, nor wish to make an exhibition of my oratorical powers, yet have I felt it my duty to record plainly the singular virtues with which the emperor is endowed: for I am persuaded that silence concerning them, as they are so excellent, would be injustice to those who should come after us.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:4
verses.text: In the first place then, this prince though born and nurtured to empire, was neither stultified nor effeminated by the circumstances of his birth and education.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:5
verses.text: He evinced so much prudence, that he appeared to those who conversed with him to have acquired wisdom from experience.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:6
verses.text: Such was his fortitude in undergoing hardships, that he would courageously endure both heat and cold; fasting very frequently, especially on Wednesdays and Fridays;  and this he did from an earnest endeavor to observe with accuracy all the prescribed forms of the Christian religion.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:7
verses.text: He rendered his palace little different from a monastery: for he, together with his sisters, rose early in the morning, and recited responsive hymns in praise of the Deity.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:8
verses.text: By this training he learnt the holy Scriptures by heart; and he would often discourse with the bishops on scriptural subjects, as if he had been an ordained priest of long standing.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:9
verses.text: He was a more indefatigable collector of the sacred books and of the expositions which had been written on them, than even Ptolemy Philadelphus  had formerly been.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:10
verses.text: In clemency and humanity he far surpassed all others.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:11
verses.text: For the emperor Julian although he professed to be a philosopher, could not moderate his rage against the Antiochians who derided him, but inflicted upon Theodore the most agonizing tortures.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:12
verses.text: Theodosius on the contrary, bidding farewell to Aristotle's syllogisms, exercised philosophy in deeds, by getting the mastery over anger, grief, and pleasure.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:13
verses.text: Never has he revenged himself on any one by whom he has been injured; nor has any one ever even seen him irritated.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:14
verses.text: And when some of his most intimate friends once asked him, why he never inflicted capital punishment upon offenders, his answer was, 'Would that it were even possible to restore to life those that have died.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:15
verses.text: ' To another making a similar inquiry he replied, 'It is neither a great nor a difficult thing for a mortal to be put to death but it is God only that can resuscitate by repentance a person that has once died.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:16
verses.text: ' So habitually indeed did he practice mercy, that if any one were guilty and sentence of death was passed upon him, and he was conducted toward the place of execution, he was never suffered to reach the gates of the city before a pardon was issued, commanding his immediate return.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:17
verses.text: Having once exhibited a show of hunting wild beasts in the Amphitheatre at Constantinople, the people cried out, 'Let one of the boldest bestiarii  encounter the enraged animal.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:18
verses.text: ' But he said to them, 'Do ye not know that we are wont to view these spectacles with feelings of humanity?' By this expression he instructed the people to be satisfied in future with shows of a less cruel description.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:19
verses.text: His piety was such that he had a reverential regard for all who were consecrated to the service of God; and honored in an especial manner those whom he ascertained to be eminent for their sanctity of life.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:20
verses.text: It is said that the bishop of Chebron  having died at Constantinople, the emperor expressed a wish to have his cassock of sackcloth of hair; which, although it was excessively filthy, he wore as a cloak, hoping that thus he should become a partaker in some degree of the sanctity of the deceased.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:21
verses.text: In a certain year, during which the weather had been very tempestuous, he was obliged by the eagerness of the people to exhibit the usual sports in the Hippodrome; and when the circus was filled with spectators, the violence of the storm increased, and there was a heavy fall of snow.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:22
verses.text: Then the emperor made it very evident how his mind was affected towards God; for he caused the herald to make a proclamation to the people to this effect: 'It is far better and fitter to desist from the show, and unite in common prayer to God, that we may be preserved unhurt from the impending storm.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:23
verses.text: ' Scarcely had the herald executed his commission, when all the people, with the greatest joy, began with one accord to offer supplication and sing praises to God, so that the whole city became one vast congregation; and the emperor himself in official garments, went into the midst of the multitude and commenced the hymns.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:24
verses.text: Nor was he disappointed in his expectation, for the atmosphere began to resume its wonted serenity: and Divine benevolence bestowed on all an abundant harvest, instead of an expected deficiency of corn.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:25
verses.text: If at any time war was raised, like David he had recourse to God, knowing that he is the arbiter of battles, and by prayer brought them to a prosperous issue.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:26
verses.text: At this point therefore, I shall relate, how a little after the war against the Persians, by placing his confidence in God he vanquished the usurper John, after Honorius had died on the 15th of August, in the consulate of Asclepiodotus and Marian.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:27
verses.text: For I judge what then occurred worthy of mention, inasmuch as there happened to the emperor's generals who were dispatched against the tyrant, something analogous to what took place when the Israelites crossed the Red Sea under the guidance of Moses.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 22:28
verses.text: These things however, I shall set forth very briefly, leaving to others the numerous details which would require a special treatise.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:2
verses.text: —After the Death of the Emperor Honorius John usurps the Sovereignty at Rome.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:3
verses.text: He is destroyed through the Prayers of Theodosius the Younger.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:4
verses.text: When the Emperor Honorius died Theodosius—now sole ruler—having received the news concealed the truth as long as possible, misleading the people sometimes with one report, and then with another.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:5
verses.text: But he privately dispatched a military force to Salonae, a city of Dalmatia, that in the event of any revolutionary movement in the West there might be resources at hand to check it; and after making these provisional arrangements, he at length openly announced his uncle's death.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:6
verses.text: In the meantime John, the superintendent of the emperor's secretaries,  not content with the dignity to which he had already attained, seized upon the sovereign authority; and sent an embassy to the emperor Theodosius, requesting that he might be recognized as his colleague in the empire.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:7
verses.text: But that prince first caused the ambassadors to be arrested, then sent off Ardaburius, the commander-in-chief of the army, who had greatly distinguished himself in the Persian war.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:8
verses.text: He, on arriving at Salonae, set sail from thence for Aquileia.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:9
verses.text: And he was fortunate as was thought, but fortune was adverse to him as it afterwards appeared.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:10
verses.text: For a contrary wind having arisen, he was driven into the usurper's hand.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:11
verses.text: The latter having seized him became more sanguine in his hope that the emperor would be induced by the urgency of the case to elect and proclaim him emperor, in order to preserve the life of his general-in-chief.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:12
verses.text: And the emperor was in fact greatly distressed when he heard of it, as was also the army which had been sent against the usurper, lest Ardaburius should be subjected to evil treatment by the usurper.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:13
verses.text: Aspar the son of Ardaburius, having learnt that his father was in the usurper's power, and aware at the same time that the party of the rebels was strengthened by the accession of immense numbers of barbarians, knew not what course to pursue.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:14
verses.text: Then again at this crisis the prayer of the pious emperor prevailed.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:15
verses.text: For an angel of God, under the appearance of a shepherd, undertook the guidance of Aspar and the troops which were with him, and led him through the lake near Ravenna—for in that city the usurper was then residing—and there detained the military chief.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:16
verses.text: Now, no one had ever been known to have forded that lake before; but God then rendered that passable, which had hitherto been impassable.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:17
verses.text: Having therefore crossed the lake, as if going over dry ground, they found the gates of the city open, and overpowered the usurper.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:18
verses.text: This event afforded that most devout emperor an opportunity of giving a fresh demonstration of his piety towards God.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:19
verses.text: For the news of the usurper's being destroyed, having arrived while he was engaged at the exhibition of the sports of the Hippodrome, he immediately said to the people: 'Come now, if you please, let us leave these diversions, and proceed to the church to offer thanksgivings to God, whose hand has overthrown the usurper.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:20
verses.text: ' Thus did he address them; and the spectacles were immediately forsaken and neglected, the people all passing out of the circus singing praises together with him, as with one heart and one voice.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 23:21
verses.text: And arriving at the church, the whole city again became one congregation; and once in the church they passed the remainder of the day in these devotional exercises.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 24:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIV.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 24:2
verses.text: —Valentinian a Son of Constantius and Placidia, Aunt of Theodosius, is proclaimed Emperor.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 24:3
verses.text: After the usurper's death, the emperor Theodosius became very anxious as to whom he should proclaim emperor of the West.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 24:4
verses.text: He had a cousin then very young named Valentinian; the son of his aunt Placidia, daughter of Theodosius the Great, and sister of the two Augusti Arcadius and Honorius and of that Constantius who had been proclaimed emperor by Honorius,  and had died after a short reign with him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 24:5
verses.text: This cousin he created Caesar, and sent into the Western parts, committing the administration of affairs to his mother Placidia.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 24:6
verses.text: He himself also hastened towards Italy, that he might in person both proclaim his cousin emperor, and also being present among them, endeavor to influence the natives and residents by his counsels not to submit to usurpers readily.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 24:7
verses.text: But when he reached Thessalonica he was prevented from proceeding further by sickness; he therefore sent forward the imperial crown to his cousin by Helion the patrician, and he himself returned to Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 24:8
verses.text: But concerning these matters I deem the narrative here given sufficient.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:1
verses.text: Chapter XXV.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:2
verses.text: —Christian Benevolence of Atticus Bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:3
verses.text: He registers John's Name in the Diptychs.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:4
verses.text: His Fore-knowledge of his Own Death.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:5
verses.text: Meanwhile Atticus the bishop caused the affairs of the church to flourish in an extraordinary manner; administering all things with prudence, and inciting the people to virtue by his instruction.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:6
verses.text: Perceiving that the church was on the point of being divided inasmuch as the Johannites  assembled themselves apart, he ordered that mention of John should be made in the prayers, as was customary to be done of the other deceased  bishops; by which means he trusted that many would be induced to return to the Church.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:7
verses.text: And he was so liberal that he not only provided for the poor of his own parishes, but transmitted contributions to supply the wants and promote the comfort of the indigent in the neighboring cities also.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:8
verses.text: On one occasion as he sent to Calliopius a presbyter of the church at Nicaea, three hundred pieces  of gold he also dispatched the following letter.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:9
verses.text: 'Atticus to Calliopius—salutations in the Lord.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:10
verses.text: 'I have been informed that there are in your city ten thousand necessitous persons whose condition demands the compassion of the pious.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:11
verses.text: And I say ten thousand, designating their multitude rather than using the number precisely.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:12
verses.text: As therefore I have received a sum of money from him, who with a bountiful hand is wont to supply faithful stewards; and since it happens that some are pressed by want, that those who have may be proved, who yet do not minister to the needy—take, my friend, these three hundred pieces of gold, and dispose of them as you may think fit.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:13
verses.text: It will be your care, I doubt not, to distribute to such as are ashamed to beg, and not to those who through life have sought to feed themselves at others' expense.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:14
verses.text: In bestowing these alms make no distinction on religious grounds; but feed the hungry whether they agree with us in sentiment, or not.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:15
verses.text: '  Thus did Atticus consider even the poor who were at a distance from him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:16
verses.text: He labored also to abolish the superstitions of certain persons.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:17
verses.text: For on being informed that those who had separated themselves from the Novatians, on account of the Jewish Passover, had transported the body of Sabbatius  from the island of Rhodes—for in that island he had died in exile—and having buried it, were accustomed to pray at his grave, he caused the body to be disinterred at night, and deposited in a private sepulchre; and those who had formerly paid their adorations at that place, on finding his tomb had been opened, ceased honoring that tomb thenceforth.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:18
verses.text: Moreover he manifested a great deal of taste in the application of names to places.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:19
