verses.text: To a port in the mouth of the Euxine sea, anciently called Pharmaceus,  he gave the appellation of Therapeia;  because he would not have a place where religious assemblies were held, dishonored by an inauspicious name.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:20
verses.text: Another place, a suburb of Constantinople, he termed Argyropolis,  for this reason.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:21
verses.text: Chrysopolis  is an ancient port situated at the head of the Bosphorus, and is mentioned by several of the early writers, especially Strabo, Nicolaus Damascenus, and the illustrious Xenophon in the sixth book of his Anabasis of Cyrus;  and again in the first of his Hellenica  he says concerning it, 'that Alcibiades having walled it round, established a toll in it; for all who sailed out of Pontus were accustomed to pay tithes there.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:22
verses.text: ' Atticus seeing the former place to be directly opposite to Chrysopolis, and very delightfully situated, declared that it was most fitting it should be called Argyropolis; and as soon as this was said it firmly established the name.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:23
verses.text: Some persons having said to him that the Novatians ought not to be permitted to hold their assemblies within the cities: 'Do you not know,' he replied, 'that they were fellow-sufferers with us in the persecution under Constantius and Valens?  Besides,' said he, 'they are witnesses to our creed: for although they separated from the church a long while ago, they have never introduced any innovations concerning the faith.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:24
verses.text: ' Being once at Nicaea on account of the ordination of a bishop, and seeing there Asclepiades bishop of the Novatians, then very aged, he asked him, 'How many years have you been a bishop?' When he was answered fifty years: 'You are a happy man,' said he, 'to have had charge of so "good a work"  for such a length of time.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:25
verses.text: ' To the same Asclepiades he observed: 'I commend Novatus; but can by no means approve of the Novatians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:26
verses.text: ' And when Asclepiades, surprised at this strange remark, said, 'What is the meaning of your remark, bishop?' Atticus gave him this reason for the distinction.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:27
verses.text: 'I approve of Novatus for refusing to commune with those who had sacrificed, for I myself would have done the same: but I cannot praise the Novatians, inasmuch as they exclude laymen from communion for very trivial offenses.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:28
verses.text: ' Asclepiades answered, 'There are many other "sins unto death,"  as the Scriptures term them, besides sacrificing to idols; on account of which even you excommunicate ecclesiastics only, but we laymen also, reserving to God alone the power of pardoning them.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:29
verses.text: '  Atticus had moreover a presentiment of his own death; for at his departure from Nicaea, he said to Calliopius a presbyter of that place: 'Hasten to Constantinople before autumn if you wish to see me again alive; for if you delay beyond that time, you will not find me surviving.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:30
verses.text: ' Nor did he err in this prediction; for he died on the 10th of October, in the 21st year of his episcopate, under the eleventh consulate of Theodosius, and the first of Valentinian Caesar.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:31
verses.text: The Emperor Theodosius indeed, being then on his way from Thessalonica, did not reach Constantinople in time for his funeral, for Atticus had been consigned to the grave one day before the emperor's arrival.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 25:32
verses.text: Not long afterwards, on the 23d of the same month, October, the young Valentinian was proclaimed Augustus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 26:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVI.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 26:2
verses.text: —Sisinnius is chosen to succeed Atticus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 26:3
verses.text: After the decease of Atticus, there arose a strong contest about the election of a successor, some proposing one person, and some another.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 26:4
verses.text: One party, they say, was urgent in favor of a presbyter named Philip; another wished to promote Proclus who was also a presbyter; but the general desire of the people was that the bishopric should be conferred on Sisinnius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 26:5
verses.text: This person was also a presbyter but held no ecclesiastical office within the city, having been appointed to the sacred ministry in a church at Elaea, a village in the suburbs of Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 26:6
verses.text: This village is situated across the harbor from the city, and in it from an ancient custom the whole population annually assembled for the celebration of our Saviour's ascension.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 26:7
verses.text: All of the laity were warmly attached to the man because he was famous for his piety, and especially because he was diligent in the care of the poor even 'beyond his power.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 26:8
verses.text: '  The earnestness of the laity thus prevailed, and Sisinnius was ordained on the twenty-eighth day of February, under the following consulate, which was the twelfth of Theodosius, and the second of Valentinian.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 26:9
verses.text: The presbyter Philip was so chagrined at the preference of another to himself, that he even introduced the subject into his Christian History,  making some very censorious remarks, both about the person ordained and those who had ordained him, and much more severely on the laity.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 26:10
verses.text: But he said such things as I cannot by any means commit to writing.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 26:11
verses.text: Since I do not approve of his unadvised action in committing them to writing, I do not deem it unseasonable, however, to give some notice here of him and of his works.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 27:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 27:2
verses.text: —Voluminous Productions of Philip, a Presbyter of Side.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 27:3
verses.text: Philip was a native of Side; Side is a city of Pamphylia.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 27:4
verses.text: From this place also Troïlus the sophist came, to whom Philip boasted himself to be nearly related.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 27:5
verses.text: He was a deacon and thus admitted to the privilege of familiar intercourse with John Chrysostom, the bishop.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 27:6
verses.text: He labored assiduously in literature, and besides making very considerable literary attainments, formed an extensive collection of books in every branch of knowledge.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 27:7
verses.text: Affecting the Asiatic style,  he became the author of many treatises, attempting among others a refutation of the Emperor Julian's treatises against the Christians, and compiled a Christian History, which he divided into thirty-six books; each of these books occupied several volumes, so that they amounted altogether to nearly one thousand, and the mere argument  of each volume equalled in magnitude the volume itself.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 27:8
verses.text: This composition he has entitled not an Ecclesiastical, but a Christian History, and has grouped together in it abundance of very heterogeneous materials, wishing to show that he is not ignorant of philosophical and scientific learning: for it contains a medley of geometrical theorems, astronomical speculations, arithmetical calculations, and musical principles, with geographical delineations of islands, mountains, forests, and various other matters of little moment.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 27:9
verses.text: By forcing such irrelevant details into connection with his subject, he has rendered his work a very loose production, useless alike, in my opinion, to the ignorant and the learned; for the illiterate are incapable of appreciating the loftiness of his diction, and such as are really competent to form a just estimate, condemn his wearisome tautology.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 27:10
verses.text: But let every one exercise his own judgment concerning these books according to his taste.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 27:11
verses.text: All I have to add is, that he has confounded the chronological order of the transactions he describes: for after having related what took place in the reign of the Emperor Theodosius, he immediately goes back to the times of the bishop Athanasius; and this sort of thing he does frequently.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 27:12
verses.text: But enough has been said of Philip: we must now mention what happened under the episcopate of Sisinnius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 28:1
verses.text: Chapter XXVIII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 28:2
verses.text: —Proclus ordained Bishop of Cyzicus by Sisinnius, but rejected by the People.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 28:3
verses.text: The bishop of Cyzicus having died, Sisinnius ordained Proclus to the bishopric of that city.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 28:4
verses.text: But while he was preparing to depart thither, the inhabitants anticipated him, by electing an ascetic named Dalmatius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 28:5
verses.text: This they did in disregard of a law which forbade their ordination of a bishop without the sanction of the bishop of Constantinople;  but they pretended that this was a special privilege granted to Atticus personally.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 28:6
verses.text: Proclus therefore continued destitute of the presidency over his own church, but acquired celebrity for his discourses in the churches of Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 28:7
verses.text: We shall however speak of him more particularly in an appropriate place.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 28:8
verses.text: Sisinnius having survived his appointment to the bishopric by barely two entire years, was removed by death on the 24th of December, in the consulate of Hierius and Ardaburius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 28:9
verses.text: For his temperance, integrity of life, and benignity to the poor, he was deservedly eminent; he was moreover singularly affable and guileless in disposition, and this rendered him rather averse to business, so that by men of active habits he was accounted indolent.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:1
verses.text: Chapter XXIX.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:2
verses.text: —Nestorius of Antioch promoted to the See of Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:3
verses.text: His Persecution of the Heretics.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:4
verses.text: After the death of Sisinnius, on account of the spirit of ambitious rivalry displayed by the ecclesiastics of Constantinople, the emperors resolved that none of that church should fill the vacant bishopric, notwithstanding the fact that many eagerly desired to have Philip ordained, and no less a number were in favor of the election of Proclus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:5
verses.text: They therefore sent for a stranger  from Antioch, whose name was Nestorius,  a native of Germanicia,  distinguished for his excellent voice and fluency of speech; qualifications which they judged important for the instruction of the people.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:6
verses.text: After three months had elapsed therefore, Nestorius was brought from Antioch, being greatly lauded by some for his temperance: but what sort of a disposition he was of in other respects, those who possessed any discernment were able to perceive from his first sermon.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:7
verses.text: Being ordained on the 10th of April, under the consulate of Felix and Taurus,  he immediately uttered those famous words, before all the people, in addressing the emperor, 'Give me, my prince, the earth purged of heretics, and I will give you heaven as a recompense.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:8
verses.text: Assist me in destroying heretics, and I will assist you in vanquishing the Persians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:9
verses.text: '  Now although these utterances were extremely gratifying to some of the multitude, who cherished a senseless antipathy to the very name of heretic; yet those, as I have said, who were skillful in predicating a man's character from his expressions, did not fail to detect his levity of mind, and violent and vainglorious temperament, inasmuch as he had burst forth into such vehemence without being able to contain himself for even the shortest space of time; and to use the proverbial phrase, 'before he had tasted the water of the city,' showed himself a furious persecutor.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:10
verses.text: Accordingly on the fifth day after his ordination, having determined to demolish a chapel in which the Arians were accustomed to perform their devotions privately, he drove these people to desperation; for when they saw the work of destruction going forward in their chapel, they threw fire into it, and the fire spreading on all sides reduced many of the adjacent buildings also to ashes.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:11
verses.text: A tumult accordingly arose on account of this throughout the city, and the Arians burning to revenge themselves, made preparations for that purpose: but God the Guardian of the city suffered not the mischief to gather to a climax.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:12
verses.text: From that time, however, they branded Nestorius as an 'incendiary,' and it was not only the heretics who did this, but those also of his own faith.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:13
verses.text: For he could not rest, but seeking every means of harassing those who embraced not his own sentiments, he continually disturbed the public tranquillity.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:14
verses.text: He annoyed the Novatians also, being incited to jealousy because Paul their bishop was everywhere respected for his piety; but the emperor by his admonitions checked his fury.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:15
verses.text: With what calamities he visited the Quartodecimans throughout Asia, Lydia, and Caria, and what multitudes perished in a popular tumult of which he was the cause at Miletus and Sardis, I think proper to pass by in silence.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 29:16
verses.text: What punishment he suffered for all these enormities, and for that unbridled license of speech in which he indulged himself, I shall mention somewhat later.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 30:1
verses.text: Chapter XXX.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 30:2
verses.text: —The Burgundians embrace Christianity under Theodosius the Younger.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 30:3
verses.text: I must now relate an event well worthy of being recorded, which happened about this time.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 30:4
verses.text: There is a barbarous nation dwelling beyond the Rhine, denominated Burgundians; they lead a peaceful life; for being almost all artisans, they support themselves by the exercise of their trades.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 30:5
verses.text: The Huns, by making continual irruptions on this people, devastated their country, and often destroyed great numbers of them.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 30:6
verses.text: In this perplexity, therefore, the Burgundians resolved to have recourse not to any human being, but to commit themselves to the protection of some god: and having seriously considered that the God of the Romans mightily defended those that feared him, they all with common consent embraced the faith of Christ.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 30:7
verses.text: Going therefore to one of the cities of Gaul, they requested the bishop to grant them Christian baptism: who ordering them to fast seven days, and having meanwhile instructed them in the elementary principles of the faith, on the eighth day baptized and dismissed them.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 30:8
verses.text: Accordingly becoming confident thenceforth, they marched against their invaders; nor were they disappointed in their hope.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 30:9
verses.text: For the king of the Huns, Uptar  by name, having died in the night from the effects of a surfeit, the Burgundians attacked that people then without a commander-in-chief; and although they were few in numbers and their opponents very many, they obtained a complete victory; for the Burgundians were altogether but three thousand men, and destroyed no less than ten thousand of the enemy.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 30:10
verses.text: From that period this nation became zealously attached to the Christian religion.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 30:11
verses.text: About the same time Barbas bishop of the Arians died, on the 24th of June, under the thirteenth consulate of Theodosius,  and the third of Valentinian, and Sabbatius was constituted his successor.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 30:12
verses.text: Enough has been said of these matters.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 31:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXI.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 31:2
verses.text: —Nestorius harasses the Macedonians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 31:3
verses.text: Nestorius indeed acted contrary to the usage of the Church, and caused himself to be hated in other ways also,  as is evident from what happened during his episcopate.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 31:4
verses.text: For Anthony bishop of Germa, a city of the Hellespont, actuated by the example of Nestorius in his intolerance of heretics, began to persecute the Macedonians, under the pretext of carrying out the intentions of the patriarch.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 31:5
verses.text: The Macedonians for some time endured his annoyance; but when Anthony proceeded to farther extremities, unable any longer to bear his harsh treatment, they were led to a sad desperation, and suborning two men, who put right in a secondary place and profit first, they assassinated their tormenter.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 31:6
verses.text: When the Macedonians had perpetrated this crime, Nestorius took occasion from it to increase his violence of conduct against them, and prevailed on the emperor to take away their churches.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 31:7
verses.text: They were therefore deprived of not only those which they possessed at Constantinople, before the old walls of the imperial city, but of those also which they had at Cyzicus, and many others that belonged to them in the rural districts of the Hellespont.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 31:8
verses.text: Many of them therefore at that time came over to the Catholic church, and professed the 'homoousian' faith.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 31:9
verses.text: But as the proverb says, 'drunkards never want wine, nor the contentious strife': and so it fell out with regard to Nestorius, who after having exerted himself to expel others from the church, was himself ejected on the following account.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:2
verses.text: —Of the Presbyter Anastasius, by whom the Faith of Nestorius was perverted.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:3
verses.text: Nestorius had an associate whom he had brought from Antioch, a presbyter named Anastasius; for this man he had the highest esteem, and consulted him in the management of his most important affairs.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:4
verses.text: This Anastasius preaching one day in the church said, 'Let no one call Mary Theotocos:  for Mary was but a woman;  and it is impossible that God should be born of a woman.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:5
verses.text: ' These words created a great sensation, and troubled many both of the clergy and laity; they having been heretofore taught to acknowledge Christ as God, and by no means to separate his humanity from his divinity on account of the economy of incarnation, heeding the voice of the apostle when he said, 'Yea, though we have known Christ after the flesh; yet now henceforth know we him no more.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:6
verses.text: '  And again, 'Wherefore, leaving the word of the beginning of Christ, let us go on unto perfection.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:7
verses.text: '  While great offense was taken in the church, as we have said, at what was thus propounded, Nestorius, eager to establish Anastasius' proposition—for he did not wish to have the man who was esteemed by himself found guilty of blasphemy—delivered several public discourses on the subject, in which he assumed a controversial attitude, and totally rejected the epithet Theotocos.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:8
verses.text: Wherefore the controversy on the subject being taken in one spirit by some and in another by others, the discussion which ensued divided the church, and resembled the struggle of combatants in the dark, all parties uttering the most confused and contradictory assertions.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:9
verses.text: Nestorius thus acquired the reputation among the masses of asserting the blasphemous dogma that the Lord is a mere man, and attempting to foist on the Church the dogmas of Paul of Samosata and Photinus; and so great a clamor was raised by the contention that it was deemed requisite to convene a general council to take cognizance of the matter in dispute.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:10
verses.text: Having myself perused the writings of Nestorius, I have found him an unlearned man and shall candidly express the conviction of my own mind concerning him: and as in entire freedom from personal antipathies, I have already alluded to his faults, I shall in like manner be unbiassed by the criminations of his adversaries, to derogate from his merits.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:11
verses.text: I cannot then concede that he was either a follower of Paul of Samosata or of Photinus, or that he denied the Divinity of Christ: but he seemed scared at the term Theotocos, as though it were some terrible phantom.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:12
verses.text: The fact is, the causeless alarm he manifested on this subject just exposed his extreme ignorance: for being a man of natural fluency as a speaker, he was considered well educated, but in reality he was disgracefully illiterate.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:13
verses.text: In fact he contemned the drudgery of an accurate examination of the ancient expositors: and, puffed up with his readiness of expression, he did not give his attention to the ancients, but thought himself the greatest of all.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:14
verses.text: Now he was evidently unacquainted with the fact that in the First Catholic epistle of John it was written in the ancient copies,  'Every spirit that separates Jesus, is not of God.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:15
verses.text: ' The mutilation of this passage  is attributable to those who desired to separate the Divine nature from the human economy: or to use the very language of the early interpreters, some persons have corrupted this epistle, aiming at 'separating the manhood of Christ from his Deity.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:16
verses.text: ' But the humanity is united to the Divinity in the Saviour, so as to constitute not two persons but one only.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:17
verses.text: Hence it was that the ancients, emboldened by this testimony, scrupled not to style Mary Theotocos.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:18
verses.text: For thus Eusebius Pamphilus in his third book of the Life of Constantine  writes in these terms:      'And in fact "God with us" submitted to be born for our sake; and the place of his nativity is by the Hebrews called Bethlehem.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:19
verses.text: Wherefore the devout empress Helena adorned the place of accouchement of the God-bearing virgin with the most splendid monuments, decorating that sacred spot with the richest ornaments.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:20
verses.text: '  Origen also in the first volume of his Commentaries on the apostle's epistle to the Romans,  gives an ample exposition of the sense in which the term Theotocos is used.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:21
verses.text: It is therefore obvious that Nestorius had very little acquaintance with the treatises of the ancients, and for that reason, as I observed, objected to the word only: for that he does not assert Christ to be a mere man, as Photinus did or Paul of Samosata, his own published homilies fully demonstrate.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:22
verses.text: In these discourses he nowhere destroys the proper personality  of the Word of God; but on the contrary invariably maintains that he has an essential and distinct personality and existence.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:23
verses.text: Nor does he ever deny his subsistence as Photinus and the Samosatan did, and as the Manichaeans and followers of Montanus have also dared to do.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:24
verses.text: Such in fact I find Nestorius, both from having myself read his own works, and from the assurances of his admirers.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 32:25
verses.text: But this idle contention of his has produced no slight ferment in the religious world.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 33:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 33:2
verses.text: —Desecration of the Altar of the Great Church by Runaway Slaves.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 33:3
verses.text: While matters were in this state it happened that an outrage was perpetrated in the church.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 33:4
verses.text: For the domestics of a man of quality who were foreigners, having experienced harsh treatment from their master, fled from him to the church; and thus they ran up to the very altar with their swords drawn.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 33:5
verses.text: Nor could they be prevailed upon by any entreaties to withdraw; so that they impeded the performance of the sacred services; but inasmuch as they obstinately maintained their position for several days, brandishing their weapons in defiance of any one who dared to approach them—and in fact killed one of the ecclesiastics, and wounded another—they were finally compelled to slay themselves.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 33:6
verses.text: A person who was present at this desecration of the sanctuary, remarked that such a profanation was an ominous presage, and in support of his view of the matter, quoted the two following iambics of an ancient poet:—      "For such prognostics happen at a time  When temples are defiled by impious crime".

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 33:7
verses.text: Nor was he who made the prediction disappointed in these inauspicious forebodings: for they signified as it seems a division among the people, and the deposition of the author of it.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIV.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:2
verses.text: —Synod at Ephesus against Nestorius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:3
verses.text: His Deposition.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:4
verses.text: Not long time elapsed before a mandate from the emperor directed the bishops in all places to assemble at Ephesus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:5
verses.text: Immediately after the festival of Easter therefore Nestorius, escorted by a great crowd of his adherents, repaired to Ephesus, and found many of the bishops already there.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:6
verses.text: Cyril bishop of Alexandria making some delay, did not arrive till near Pentecost.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:7
verses.text: Five days after Pentecost, Juvenal bishop of Jerusalem arrived.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:8
verses.text: While John of Antioch was still absent, those who were now congregated entered into the consideration of the question; and Cyril of Alexandria began a sharp skirmish of words, with the design of terrifying Nestorius, for he had a strong dislike for him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:9
verses.text: When many had declared that Christ was God, Nestorius said: 'I cannot term him God who was two and three months old.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:10
verses.text: I am therefore clear of your blood, and shall in future come no more among you.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:11
verses.text: ' Having uttered these words he left the assembly, and afterwards held meetings with the other bishops who entertained sentiments similar to his own.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:12
verses.text: Accordingly those present were divided into two factions.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:13
verses.text: That section which supported Cyril, having constituted themselves a council, summoned Nestorius: but he refused to meet them, and put them off until the arrival of John of Antioch.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:14
verses.text: The partisans of Cyril therefore proceeded to the examination of the public discourses of Nestorius which he had preached on the subject in dispute; and after deciding from a repeated perusal of them that they contained distinct blasphemy against the Son of God, they deposed him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:15
verses.text: This being done, the partisans of Nestorius constituted themselves another council apart, and therein deposed Cyril himself, and together with him Memnon bishop of Ephesus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:16
verses.text: Not long after these events, John bishop of Antioch made his appearance; and being informed of what had taken place, he pronounced unqualified censure on Cyril as the author of all this confusion, in having so precipitately proceeded to the deposition of Nestorius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:17
verses.text: Upon this Cyril combined with Juvenal to revenge themselves on John, and they deposed him also.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:18
verses.text: When affairs reached this confused condition, Nestorius saw that the contention which had been raised was thus tending to the destruction of communion, in bitter regret he called Mary Theotocos, and cried out: 'Let Mary be called Theotocos, if you will, and let all disputing cease.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:19
verses.text: ' But although he made this recantation, no notice was taken of it; for his deposition was not revoked, and he was banished to the Oasis, where he still remains.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:20
verses.text: Such was the conclusion of this Synod.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:21
verses.text: These things were done on the 28th of June, under the consulate of Bassus and Antiochus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:22
verses.text: John when he had returned to his bishopric, having convened several bishops, deposed Cyril, who had also returned to his see: but soon afterwards, having set aside their enmity and accepting each other as friends, they mutually reinstated each other in their episcopal chairs.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:23
verses.text: But after the deposition of Nestorius a mighty agitation prevailed through the churches of Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:24
verses.text: For the people was divided on account of what we have already called his unfortunate utterances; and the clergy unanimously anathematized him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 34:25
verses.text: For such is the sentence which we Christians are accustomed to pronounce on those who have advanced any blasphemous doctrines, when we set up their impiety that it may be publicly exposed, as it were, on a pillar, to universal execration.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 35:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXV.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 35:2
verses.text: —Maximian elected to the Episcopate of Constantinople, though Some wished Proclus to take that Place.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 35:3
verses.text: After this there was another debate concerning the election of a bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 35:4
verses.text: Many were in favor of Philip, of whom we have already made mention; but a still greater number advocated the claims of Proclus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 35:5
verses.text: And the candidacy of Proclus would have succeeded, had not some of the most influential persons interfered, on the ground of its being forbidden by the ecclesiastical canon that a person nominated to one bishopric should be translated to that of another city.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 35:6
verses.text: The people believing this assertion, were thereby restrained; and about four months after the deposition of Nestorius, a man named Maximian was promoted to the bishopric, who had lived an ascetic life, and was also ranked as a presbyter.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 35:7
verses.text: He had acquired a high reputation for sanctity, on account of having at his own expense constructed sepulchral depositaries for the reception of the pious after their decease, but was 'rude in speech'  and inclined to live a quiet life.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVI.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:2
verses.text: —The Author's Opinion of the Validity of Translations from One See to Another.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:3
verses.text: But since some parties by appealing to a prohibition in the ecclesiastical canon, prevented the election of Proclus, because of his previous appointment to the see of Cyzicus, I wish to make a few remarks on this subject.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:4
verses.text: Those who then presumed to interpose such a cause of exclusion do not appear to me to have stated the truth; but they were either influenced by prejudice against Proclus, or at least have been themselves completely ignorant both of the canons, and of the frequent and often advantageous precedents that had been established in the churches.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:5
verses.text: Eusebius Pamphilus relates in the sixth book of his Ecclesiastical History,  that Alexander bishop of a certain city in Cappadocia, coming to Jerusalem for devotional purposes, was detained by the inhabitants of that city, and constituted bishop, as the successor of Narcissus; and that he continued to preside over the churches there during the remainder of his life.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:6
verses.text: So indifferent a thing was it amongst our ancestors, to transfer a bishop from one city to another as often as it was deemed expedient.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:7
verses.text: But if it is necessary to place beyond a doubt the falsehood of the statement of those who prevented the ordination of Proclus, I shall annex to this treatise the canon bearing on the subject.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:8
verses.text: It runs thus:      'If any one after having been ordained a bishop should not proceed to the church unto which he has been appointed, from no fault on his part, but either because the people are unwilling to receive him, or for some other reason arising from necessity, let him be partaker of the honor and functions of the rank with which he has been invested, provided he intermeddles not with the affairs of the church wherein he may minister.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:9
verses.text: It is his duty however to submit to whatever the Synod of the province may see fit to determine, after it shall have taken cognizance of the matter.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:10
verses.text: '  Such is the language of the canon.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:11
verses.text: That many bishops have been transferred from one city to another to meet the exigencies of peculiar cases, I shall now prove by giving the names of those bishops who have been so translated.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:12
verses.text: Perigenes was ordained bishop of Patrae: but inasmuch as the inhabitants of that city refused to admit him, the bishop of Rome directed that he should be assigned to the metropolitan see of Corinth, which had become vacant by the decease of its former bishop; here he presided during the rest of his days.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:13
verses.text: Gregory was first made bishop of Sasima, one of the cities of Cappadocia, but was afterwards transferred to Nazianzus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:14
verses.text: Melitius after having presided over the church at Sebastia, subsequently governed that of Antioch.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:15
verses.text: Alexander bishop of Antioch transferred Dositheus bishop of Seleucia, to Tarsus in Cilicia.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:16
verses.text: Reverentius was removed from Arca in Phoenicia, and afterwards to Tyre.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:17
verses.text: John was transferred from Gordum a city of Lydia, to Proconnesus, and presided over the church there.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:18
verses.text: Palladius was transferred from Helenopolis to Aspuna; and Alexander from the same city to Adriani.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:19
verses.text: Theophilus was removed from Apamea in Asia, to Eudoxiopolis anciently called Salambria.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:20
verses.text: Polycarp was transferred from Sexantaprista a city of Mysia, to Nicopolis in Thrace.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:21
verses.text: Hierophilus from Trapezopolis in Phrygia to Plotinopolis in Thrace.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:22
verses.text: Optimus from Agdamia in Phrygia to Antioch in Pisidia; and Silvanus from Philippopolis in Thrace to Troas.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 36:23
verses.text: This enumeration of bishops who have passed from one see to another is sufficient for the present; concerning Silvanus who was removed from Philippopolis in Thrace to Troas I deem it desirable here to give a concise account.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:2
verses.text: —Miracle performed by Silvanus Bishop of Troas formerly of Philippopolis.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:3
verses.text: Silvanus was formerly a rhetorician, and had been brought up in the school of Troïlus the sophist; but aiming at perfection in his Christian course, he entered on the ascetic mode of life, and set aside the rhetorician's pallium.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:4
verses.text: Atticus bishop of Constantinople having taken notice of him afterwards ordained him bishop of Philippopolis.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:5
verses.text: Thus he resided three years in Thrace; but being unable to endure the cold of that region—for his constitution was delicate and sickly—he begged Atticus to appoint some one else in his place, alleging that it was for no other reason but the cold that he resigned residence in Thrace.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:6
verses.text: This having been done, Silvanus resided at Constantinople, where he practiced so great austerities that, despising the luxurious refinements of the age, he often appeared in the crowded streets of that populous city shod with sandals made of hay.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:7
verses.text: Some time having elapsed, the bishop of Troas died; on which account the inhabitants of that city came to Atticus concerning the appointment of a successor.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:8
verses.text: While he was deliberating whom he should ordain for them, Silvanus happened to pay him a visit, which at once relieved him from further anxiety; for addressing Silvanus, he said: 'You have now no longer any excuse for avoiding the pastoral administration of a church; for Troas is not a cold place: so that God has considered your infirmity of body, and provided you a suitable residence.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:9
verses.text: Go thither then, my brother, without delay.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:10
verses.text: ' Silvanus therefore removed to that city.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:11
verses.text: Here a miracle was performed by his instrumentality, which I shall now relate.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:12
verses.text: An immense ship for carrying burdens, such as they term 'float,'  intended for the conveyance of enormous pillars, had been recently constructed on the shore at Troas.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:13
verses.text: This vessel it was necessary to launch.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:14
verses.text: But although many strong ropes were attached to it, and the power of a vast number of persons was applied, the vessel was in no way moved.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:15
verses.text: When these attempts had been repeated several days successively with the like result, the people began to think that a devil detained the ship; they therefore went to the bishop Silvanus, and entreated him to go and offer a prayer in that place.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:16
verses.text: For thus only they thought it could be launched.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:17
verses.text: He replied with his characteristic lowliness of mind that he was but a sinner, and that the work pertained to some one who was just and not to himself.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:18
verses.text: Being at length prevailed on by their continued entreaties, he approached the shore, where after having prayed, he touched one of the ropes, and exhorting the rest to vigorous exertion, the ship was by the first pull instantly set in motion, and ran swiftly into the sea.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:19
verses.text: This miracle wrought by the hands of Silvanus, stirred up the whole population of the province to piety.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:20
verses.text: But the uncommon worth of Silvanus was manifested in various other ways.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:21
verses.text: Perceiving that the ecclesiastics made a merchandise of the contentions of those engaged in law-suits, he would never nominate any one of the clergy as judge: but causing the documents of the litigants to be delivered to himself, he summoned to him some pious layman in whose integrity he had confidence; and committing to him the adjudication of the case, he soon equitably settled all the differences of the litigants; and by this procedure Silvanus acquired for himself great reputation from all classes of persons.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:22
verses.text: We have indeed digressed pretty much from the course of our history in giving this account of Silvanus; but yet it will not, we imagine, be unprofitable.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:23
verses.text: Let us now however return to the place from which we departed.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 37:24
verses.text: Maximian, having been ordained on the 25th of October, under the consulate of Bassus and Antiochus,  the affairs of the church were reduced to a better ordered and more tranquil condition.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXVIII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:2
verses.text: —Many of the Jews in Crete embrace the Christian Faith.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:3
verses.text: About this period a great number of Jews who dwelt in Crete were convened to Christianity, through the following disastrous circumstance.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:4
verses.text: A certain Jewish impostor pretended that he was Moses, and had been  sent from heaven to lead out the Jews inhabiting that island, and conduct them through the sea: for he said that he was the same person who formerly preserved the Israelites by leading them through the Red Sea.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:5
verses.text: During a whole year therefore he perambulated the several cities of the island, and persuaded the Jews to believe such assurances.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:6
verses.text: He moreover bid them renounce their money and other property, pledging himself to guide them through a dry sea into the land of promise.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:7
verses.text: Deluded by such expectations, they neglected business of every kind, despising what they possessed, and permitting any one who chose to take it.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:8
verses.text: When the day appointed by this deceiver for their departure had arrived, he himself took the lead, and all followed with their wives and children.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:9
verses.text: He led them therefore until they reached a promontory that overhung the sea, from which he ordered them to fling themselves headlong into it.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:10
verses.text: Those who came first to the precipice did so, and were immediately destroyed, some of them being dashed in pieces against the rocks, and some drowned in the waters: and more would have perished, had not the Providence of God led some fishermen and merchants who were Christians to be present.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:11
verses.text: These persons drew out and saved some that were almost drowned, who then in their perilous situation became sensible of the madness of their conduct.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:12
verses.text: The rest they hindered from casting themselves down, by telling them of the destruction of those who had taken the first leap.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:13
verses.text: When at length the Jews perceived how fearfully they had been duped, they blamed first of all their own indiscreet credulity, and then sought to lay hold of the pseudo-Moses in order to put him to death.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:14
verses.text: But they were unable to seize him, for he suddenly disappeared which induced a general belief that it was some malignant fiend,  who had assumed a human form for the destruction of their nation in that place.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 38:15
verses.text: In consequence of this experience many of the Jews in Crete at that time abandoning Judaism attached themselves to the Christian faith.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 39:1
verses.text: Chapter XXXIX.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 39:2
verses.text: —Preservation of the Church of the Novatians from Fire.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 39:3
verses.text: A little while after this, Paul bishop of the Novatians acquired the reputation of a man truly beloved of God in a greater measure than he had before.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 39:4
verses.text: For a terrible conflagration having broken out at Constantinople, such as had never happened before,—for the fire destroyed the greater part of the city,—as the largest of the public granaries, the Achillean bath,  and everything else in the way of the fire were being consumed, it at length approached the church of the Novatians situated near Pelargus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 39:5
verses.text: When the bishop Paul saw the church endangered, he ran upon the altar, where he commended to God the preservation of the church and all it contained; nor did he cease to pray not only for it, but also for the city.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 39:6
verses.text: And God heard him, as the event clearly proved: for although the fire entered this oratory through all its doors and windows, it did no damage.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 39:7
verses.text: And while many adjacent edifices fell a prey to the devouring element, the church itself was seen unscathed in the midst of the whole conflagration triumphing over its raging flames.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 39:8
verses.text: This went on for two days and two nights, when the fire was extinguished, after it had burnt down a great part of the city: but the church remained entire, and what is more marvelous still, there was not the slightest trace even of smoke to be observed either on its timbers or its walls.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 39:9
verses.text: This occurred on the 17th of August, in the fourteenth consulate of Theodosius, which he bore together with Maximus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 39:10
verses.text: Since that time the Novatians annually celebrate the preservation of their church, on the 17th of August, by special thanksgivings to God.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 39:11
verses.text: And almost all men, Christians and most of the pagans from that time forth continue to regard that place with veneration as a peculiarly consecrated spot, because of the miracle which was wrought for its safeguard.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 39:12
verses.text: So much concerning these affairs.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 40:1
verses.text: Chapter XL.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 40:2
verses.text: —Proclus succeeds Maximian Bishop of Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 40:3
verses.text: Maximian, having peacefully governed the church during two years and five months, died on the 12th of April, in the consulate of Areobindus and Aspar.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 40:4
verses.text: This happened to be on the fifth day of the week of fasts which immediately precedes Easter.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 40:5
verses.text: The day of the week was Thursday.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 40:6
verses.text: Then the Emperor Theodosius wishing to prevent the disturbances in the church which usually attend the election of a bishop, made a wise provision for this affair; for in order that there might be no dispute again about the choice of a bishop and tumult thus arise, without delaying, before the body of Maximian was interred, he directed the bishops who were then in the city to place Proclus in the episcopal chair.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 40:7
verses.text: For he had received already letters from Caelestinus bishop of Rome approving of this election, which he had forwarded to Cyril of Alexandria, John of Antioch, and Rufus of Thessalonica; in which he assured them that there was no impediment to the translation to another see, of a person who had been nominated and really was the bishop of some one church.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 40:8
verses.text: Proclus, being thus invested with the bishopric, performed the funeral obsequies of Maximian: but it is now time briefly to give some account of him also.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 41:1
verses.text: Chapter XLI.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 41:2
verses.text: —Excellent Qualities of Proclus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 41:3
verses.text: Proclus was a reader at a very early age, and assiduously frequenting the schools, became devoted to the study of rhetoric.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 41:4
verses.text: On attaining manhood he was in the habit of constant intercourse with Atticus the bishop, having been constituted his secretary.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 41:5
verses.text: When he had made great progress, his patron promoted him to the rank of deacon; subsequently being elevated to the presbyterate, as we have before stated, he was ordained by Sisinnius to be bishop of Cyzicus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 41:6
verses.text: But all these things were done long before.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 41:7
verses.text: At this time he was allotted the episcopal chair of Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 41:8
verses.text: He was a man of moral excellence equal to any other; for having been trained by Atticus, he was a zealous imitator of all that bishop's virtues.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 41:9
verses.text: Patience, however, he exercised to a greater degree than his master, who occasionally practiced severities upon the heretics; for Proclus was gentle towards everybody, being convinced that kindness is far more effective than violence in advancing the cause of truth.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 41:10
verses.text: Resolving therefore to vexatiously interfere with no heresy whatever, he restored in his own person to the church that mild and benign dignity of character, which had so often before been unhappily violated.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 41:11
verses.text: In this respect he followed the example of the Emperor Theodosius; for as the latter had determined never to exercise his imperial authority against criminals, so had Proclus likewise purposed not to disquiet those who entertained other sentiments on divine subjects than those which he cherished himself.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 42:1
verses.text: Chapter XLII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 42:2
verses.text: —Panegyric of the Emperor Theodosius Younger.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 42:3
verses.text: For these reasons the emperor had the highest esteem for Proclus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 42:4
verses.text: For in fact he himself was a pattern to all true clergymen, and never approved of those who attempted to persecute others.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 42:5
verses.text: Nay I may venture to affirm, that in meekness he surpassed all those who have ever faithfully borne the sacerdotal office.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 42:6
verses.text: And what is recorded of Moses in the book of Numbers,  'Now the man Moses was very meek, above all the men which were upon the face of the earth'—may most justly be applied at this day; for the Emperor Theodosius is 'meek above all the men which are upon the face of the earth.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 42:7
verses.text: ' It is because of this meekness that God subdued his enemies without martial conflicts, as the capture of the usurper John,  and the subsequent discomfiture of the barbarians clearly demonstrate.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 42:8
verses.text: For the God of the universe has afforded this most devout emperor in our times supernatural aid of a similar kind to what was vouchsafed to the righteous heretofore.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 42:9
verses.text: I write not these things from adulation, but truthfully narrate facts such as everybody can attest.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 43:1
verses.text: Chapter XLIII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 43:2
verses.text: —Calamities of the Barbarians who had been the Usurper John's Allies.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 43:3
verses.text: After the death of the usurper, the barbarians whom he had called to his assistance against the Romans, made preparations for ravaging the Roman provinces.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 43:4
verses.text: The emperor being informed of this, immediately, as his custom was, committed the management of the matter to God; and continuing in earnest prayer, he speedily obtained what he sought; for it is worth while to give attention to disasters which befell the barbarians.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 43:5
verses.text: For their chief, whose name was Rougas, was struck dead with a thunderbolt.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 43:6
verses.text: Then a plague followed which destroyed most of the men who were under him: and as if this was not sufficient, fire came down from heaven, and consumed many of the survivors.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 43:7
verses.text: This filled the barbarians with the utmost terror; not so much because they had dared to take up arms against a nation of such valor as the Romans possessed, as that they perceived them to be assisted by a mighty God.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 43:8
verses.text: On this occasion, Proclus the bishop preached a sermon in the church in which he applied a prophecy out of Ezekiel to the deliverance effected by God in the late emergency, and was in consequence much admired.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 43:9
verses.text: This is the language of the prophecy:      'And thou, son of man, prophesy against Gog the prince of Rhos, Mosoch, and Thobel.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 43:10
verses.text: For I will judge him with death, and with blood, and with overflowing rain, and with hail-stones.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 43:11
verses.text: I will also rain fire and brimstone upon him, and upon all his bands, and upon many nations that are with him.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 43:12
verses.text: And I will be magnified, and glorified, and I will be known in the eyes of many nations: and they shall know that I am the Lord.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 43:13
verses.text: '  This application of the prophecy was received with great applause, as I have said, and enhanced the estimation in which Proclus was held.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 43:14
verses.text: Moreover the providence of God rewarded the meekness of the emperor in various other ways, one of which was the following.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 44:1
verses.text: Chapter XLIV.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 44:2
verses.text: —Marriage of the Emperor Valentinian with Eudoxia the Daughter of Theodosius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 44:3
verses.text: He had by the empress Eudocia, his wife, a daughter named Eudoxia.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 44:4
verses.text: Her his cousin Valentinian, appointed by him emperor of the West, demanded for himself in marriage.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 44:5
verses.text: When the emperor Theodosius had given his assent to this proposal, and they had consulted with each other as to the place on the frontiers of both empires, where it would be desirable that the marriage should be celebrated, it was decided that both parties should go to Thessalonica (which is about half-way) for this purpose.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 44:6
verses.text: But Valentinian sent a message to the effect that he would not give him the trouble of coming, for that he himself would go to Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 44:7
verses.text: Accordingly, having secured the Western parts with a sufficient guard, he proceeded thither on account of his nuptials, which were celebrated in the consulate of Isidore and Sinator;  after which he returned with his wife into the West.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 44:8
verses.text: This auspicious event took place at that time.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 45:1
verses.text: Chapter XLV.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 45:2
verses.text: —The Body of John Chrysostom transferred to Constantinople, and placed in the Church of the Apostles by the Emperor at the Instigation of Proclus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 45:3
verses.text: Not long after this, Proclus the bishop brought back to the Church those who had separated themselves from it on account of Bishop John's deposition, he having soothed the irritation by a prudent expedient.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 45:4
verses.text: What this was we must now recount.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 45:5
verses.text: Having obtained the emperor's permission, he removed the body of John from Comana, where it was buried, to Constantinople, in the thirty-fifth year after his deposition.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 45:6
verses.text: And when he had carried it in solemn procession through the city, he deposited it with much honor in the church termed The Apostles.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 45:7
verses.text: By this means the admirers of that prelate were conciliated, and again associated in communion with the [catholic] Church.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 45:8
verses.text: This happened on the 27th of January, in the sixteenth consulate of the Emperor Theodosius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 45:9
verses.text: But it astonishes me that envy, which has been vented against Origen since his death, has spared John.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 45:10
verses.text: For the former was excommunicated by Theophilus about two hundred years after his decease; while the latter was restored to communion by Proclus in the thirty-fifth year after his death! So different was Proclus from Theophilus.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 45:11
verses.text: And men of observation and intelligence cannot be deceived in reference to how these things were done and are continually being done.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVI.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:2
verses.text: —Death of Paul Bishop of the Novatians, and Election of Marcian as his Successor.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:3
verses.text: A little while after the removal of John's body, Paul bishop of the Novatians died, on the 21st of July, under the same consulate:  who at his own funeral united, in a certain sense, all the different sects into one church.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:4
verses.text: For all parties attended his body to the tomb, chanting psalms together, inasmuch as even during his lifetime by his rectitude he was in universal esteem by all.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:5
verses.text: But as Paul just before his death performed a memorable act, I deem it advantageous to insert it in this history as it may be interesting to the readers of this work to be acquainted with it.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:6
verses.text: And lest the brilliancy of that important deed should be obscured by dwelling on circumstantial details of minor consequence, I shall not stay to expatiate on the strictness with which he maintained his ascetic discipline as to diet even throughout his illness, without the least departure from the course he had prescribed for himself, or the omission of any of the ordinary exercises of devotion with his accustomed fervor.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:7
verses.text: But what was this deed? Conscious that his departure was at hand, he sent for all the presbyters of the churches under his care, and thus addressed them: 'Give your attention while I am alive to the election of a bishop to preside over you, lest the peace of your churches should hereafter be disturbed.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:8
verses.text: ' They having answered that this affair had better not be left to them: 'For inasmuch,' said they, 'as some of us have one judgment about the matter, and some another, we would by no means nominate the same individual.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:9
verses.text: We wish therefore that you would yourself designate the person you would desire to succeed you.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:10
verses.text: ' 'Give me then,' said Paul, 'this declaration of yours in writing, that you will elect him whom I should appoint.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:11
verses.text: ' When they had written this pledge, and ratified it by their signatures, Paul, rising in his bed and sitting up, wrote the name of Marcian in the paper, without informing any of those present what he had inserted.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:12
verses.text: This person had been promoted to the rank of presbyter, and instructed in the ascetic discipline by him, but was then gone abroad.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:13
verses.text: Having folded this document and put his own seal on it, he caused the principal presbyters to seal it also; after which he delivered it into the hands of Marcus a bishop of the Novatians in Scythia, who was at that time staying at Constantinople, to whom he thus spake, 'If it shall please God that I should continue much longer in this life, restore me this deposit, now entrusted to your safe keeping.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:14
verses.text: But should it seem fit to him to remove me, you will herein discover whom I have chosen as my successor in the bishopric.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:15
verses.text: ' Soon after this he died; and on the third day after his death, the paper having been unfolded in the presence of a great number of persons, Marcian's name was found within it, when they all cried out that he was worthy of the honor.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:16
verses.text: Messengers were therefore sent off without delay to bring him to Constantinople.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 46:17
verses.text: These, by a pious fraud, finding him residing at Tiberiopolis in Phrygia, brought him back with them; whereupon he was ordained and placed in the episcopal chair on the 21st of the same month.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 47:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 47:2
verses.text: —The Empress Eudocia goes to Jerusalem; sent there by the Emperor Theodosius.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 47:3
verses.text: Moreover the Emperor Theodosius offered up thanksgivings to God for the blessings which had been conferred upon him; at the same time reverencing Christ with the most special honors.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 47:4
verses.text: He also sent his wife Eudocia to Jerusalem,  she having bound herself by a vow to go thither, should she live to see the marriage of her daughter.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 47:5
verses.text: The empress therefore, on her visit to the sacred city, adorned its churches with the most costly gifts; and both then, and after her return, decorated all the churches in the other cities of the East with a variety of ornaments.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 48:1
verses.text: Chapter XLVIII.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 48:2
verses.text: —Thalassius is ordained Bishop of Caesarea in Cappadocia.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 48:3
verses.text: About this same time, under the seventeenth consulate of Theodosius,  Proclus the bishop undertook the performance of an act, such as no one among the ancients had done.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 48:4
verses.text: Firmus bishop of Caesarea in Cappadocia being dead, the inhabitants of that place came to Constantinople to consult Proclus about the appointment of a bishop.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 48:5
verses.text: While Proclus was considering whom he should prefer to that see, it so happened that all the senators came to the church to visit him on the sabbath day; among whom was Thalassius also, a man who had administered the government of the nations and cities of Illyricum.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 48:6
verses.text: And as it was reported that the emperor was about to entrust the government of the Eastern parts to him, Proclus laid his hands on him, and ordained him bishop of Caesarea, instead of Praetorian Prefect.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 48:7
verses.text: In such a flourishing condition were the affairs of the Church at this time.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 48:8
verses.text: But we shall here close our history, praying that the churches everywhere, with the cities and nations, may live in peace; for as long as peace continues, those who desire to write histories will find no materials for their purpose.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 48:9
verses.text: And we ourselves, O holy man of God, Theodore, should have been unable to accomplish in seven books the task we undertook at your request, had the lovers of seditions chosen to be quiet.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 48:10
verses.text: This last book contains an account of the transactions of thirty-two years: and the whole history which is comprised in seven books, comprehends a period of 140 years.

verses.name: Socrates: Book VII 48:11
verses.text: It commences from the first year of the 271st Olympiad, in which Constantine was proclaimed emperor; and ends at the second year of the 305th Olympiad, in which the Emperor Theodosius bore his seventeenth consulate.
